#Text=Herbs and Spices is this; That there be so much as to drown the luscious
#Text= sweetness of the Honey; but not so much as to taste of herbs or spice, when
#Text= you drink the Meathe.
#Text=But that the sweetnes of the honey may kill their
#Text= taste: And so the Meathe have a pleasant taste, but not of herbs, nor
#Text= spice, nor honey.
#Text=And therefore you put more or less according to the time
#Text= you will drink it in.
#Text=For a great deal will be mellowed away in a year,
#Text= that would be ungratefully strong in three months.
#Text=And the honey that will
#Text= make it keep a year or two, will require a triple proportion of spice and
#Text= herbs.
#Text=He commends Parsley roots to be in greatest quantity, boiled whole,
#Text= if young; but quarterred and pithed, if great and old.
#Text=MY OWN CONSIDERATIONS FOR MAKING OF MEATHE
#Text=
#Text= Boil what quantity of Spring-water you please, three or four walms, and
#Text= then let it set the twenty four hours, and pour the clear from the
#Text= settling.
#Text=Take sixteen Gallons of the clear, and boil in it ten handfuls of
#Text= Eglantine-leaves, five of Liverwort, five of Scabious, four of Baulm, four
#Text= of Rosemary; two of Bay-leaves; one of Thyme, and one of Sweet-marjoram,
#Text= and five Eringo-roots splitted.
#Text=When the water hath drawn out the vertue of
#Text=into the vessel, wherein you mean to keep it: and when it comes near the
#Text= bottom, let it be taken carefully from the sediment, with a thin Dish, so
#Text= as nothing be put into the vessel, but what is clear. 4.
#Text=Stop it very
#Text= close (when it is set in the place, where it must remain) cover it with a
#Text= cloth, upon which some handfuls of Bay-salt and Salpeter is laid, and over
#Text= that lay clay, and a Turf. 5.
#Text=Put into it, when you stop it, some
#Text= New-laid-eggs in number proportionable to the bigness of the vessel,
#Text= Shell  '  s unbroken.
#Text=Six Eggs to about sixteen Gallons.
#Text=The whole Egg-shell
#Text= and all will be entirely consumed.
#Text=METHEGLIN FOR TASTE AND COLOUR
#Text=
#Text= Must be boiled as the other, if you intend to keep it above half a year;
#Text= but less according to the time, wherein you mean to use it.
#Text=You must put in
#Text= no Herbs, to avoid bitterness and discolouring; and the proportion of water
#Text= and honey more or less, as you would drink it sooner or later; (as a Gallon
#Text= of honey to 4, 5, or 6 of water.)
#Text=If to be weak, and to be soon drunk, you
#Text= must when it is tunned, put in a Tost of bread (hard tosted) upon which
#Text= half a score drops of Spirit of yest or barm is dropped; for want of it,
#Text=spread it with purest barm beaten with a few drops of Oyl of Cinnamon.
#Text=If
#Text= you intend to give it the taste of Raspes, then adde more barm, to make it
#Text= work well, and during that time of working, put in your Raspes (or their
#Text= Syrup) but the fruit gives a delicate Colour, and Syrup a duller Tincture.
#Text=Drink not that made after the first manner, till six moneths, and it will
#Text= endure drawing better then wine; but Bottleled, it is more spirited then
#Text= any drink.
#Text=The Spirit of Barm is made by putting store of water to the barm; then
#Text= distill the Spirit, as you do other Spirits; At last an oyl will come,
#Text= which is not for this use.
#Text=Sir Thomas Gower maketh his ordinary drink thus: Make very small well
#Text= Brewed Ale.
#Text=To eight Gallons of this put one Gallon of honey; when it is
#Text= well dissolved and clarified, tun up the Liquor, making it work in due
#Text= manner with barm.
#Text=When it hath done working, stop it up close, and in three
#Text= months it will be fit to drink.
#Text=He makes Metheglin thus.
#Text=Make a good Decoct of Eglantine-leaves, Cowslip
#Text= flowers, a little Sweet-marjoram, and some Rosemary and Bay-leaves, Betony,
#Text=Liquor, after all the scum is gone; and the other half He putteth into a
#Text= bag, and hangeth in the bung, when it is tunned.
#Text=The Ginger must be very
#Text= little, not so much as to make the Liquor taste strongly of it, but to
#Text= quicken it.
#Text=I should like to adde a little proportion of Rosemary, and a
#Text= greater of Sweet-bryar leaves, in the boiling.
#Text=As also, to put into the
#Text= barrel a tost of white bread with mustard, to make it work.
#Text=He puts nothing
#Text= to it; but his own strength in time makes it work of it self.
#Text=It is good to
#Text= drink after a year.
#Text=A RECEIPT FOR WHITE METHEGLIN
#Text=
#Text= Take to every quart of honey, 4, 5, or 6, quarts of water; boil it on a
#Text= good quick fire as long as any scum riseth; as it boils, put about half a
#Text= pint of water at a time very often, and scum it very well as it riseth; and
#Text= be sure to keep it up to the same height and quantity as at the first: Put
#Text= into it a little Rosemary, according to the quantity that you make, and
#Text= boil it half a quarter of an hour; scum it very well.
#Text=You may put a little
#Text= Ginger into it, onely to give it a taste thereof, and let it have a little
#Text= walm of heat after it.
#Text=Then take and put it into a Woodden vessel, (which
#Text=must be well scalded, least it taste of any thing) let it stand all night,
#Text= and the next morning strain it through a sieve of hair.
#Text=Then if you please, you may boil up your grounds that are in the bottome of
#Text= the vessel with three or four quarts of water; and when it is cold, strain
#Text= it, to the rest, and put to it a little good light barm.
#Text=That which you
#Text= make in the winter, you must let it stand three days and three nights
#Text= covered up, before you bottle it up; and two nights in summer, and then
#Text= bottle it up.
#Text=But be sure, you scum off the barm before the bottling up.
#Text=Your Vessel, which you intend to boil your Meath in, must stand in
#Text= scalding water, whilst you boil your Meath; it will drink up the less of
#Text= your Meath.
#Text=Four spoonfuls of good new Ale-barm will serve for five quarts
#Text= of honey.
#Text=As you desire your Metheglin in strength, so take at the first
#Text= either of the quantities of water.
#Text=Five quarts is reasonable.
#Text=HYDROMEL AS I MADE IT WEAK FOR THE QUEEN MOTHER
#Text=
#Text= Take 18 quarts of spring-water, and one quart of honey; when the water is
#Text=fine Wheat-flower upon the boyling Liquor.
#Text=This will draw all the dregs to it, and swim at the top, so that you may
#Text= skim all off together.
#Text=And this she holdeth the best way of clarifying the
#Text= Liquor, and making it look pale.
#Text=Then pour it into vessels as above to
#Text= cool.
#Text=Let it stand three days; then Tun it up into a Sack cask without yest
#Text= or Spice, and keep it stopped till it work.
#Text=Then let it be open, till it
#Text= have done working, filling it up still with other honey-drink.
#Text=Then stop it
#Text= up close for a year or two.
#Text=You may at first stop it so, that the strong
#Text= working may throw out the stopple, and yet keep it close, till it work
#Text= strongly.
#Text=She saith, that such a small proportion of wormwood giveth it a
#Text= fine quick tast, and a pale colour with an eye of green.
#Text=The wormwood must
#Text= not be so much, as to discern any the least bitterness in the taste; but
#Text= that the composition of it with the honey may give a quickness.
#Text=The
#Text= Rosemary and Sage must be a great deal less then the Wormwood.
#Text=Sometimes
#Text= she stoppeth it up close as soon as she hath Tunned it, and lets it remain
#Text= so for three moneths.
#Text=Then pierce it and draw it into bottles, which stop
#Text= well, and tie down the stoppels.
#Text=This will keep so a long time.
#Text=She useth
#Text= this way most.
#Text=It makes the Mead drink exceeding quick and pleasant.
#Text=When
#Text= you pierce the Cask, it will flie out with exceeding force, and be ready to
#Text=Sweet-Majoram; half so many tops of Bays.
#Text=Boil these very well together,
#Text= and when it is cold, bottle it up.
#Text=It will be ten days before it be ready
#Text= to drink.
#Text=ANOTHER WAY OF MAKING MEATH
#Text=
#Text= Boil Sweet Bryar, Sweet Marjoram, Cloves and Mace in Spring-water, till the
#Text= water taste of them.
#Text=To four Gallons of water put one Gallon of honey, and
#Text= boil it a little to skim and clarifie it.
#Text=When you are ready to take it
#Text= from the fire, put in a little Limon-peel, and pour it into a Woodden
#Text= vessel, and let it stand till it is almost cold.
#Text=Then put in some Ale-yest,
#Text= and stir it altogether.
#Text=So let it stand till next day.
#Text=Then put a few
#Text= stoned Raisins of the Sun into every bottle, and pour the Meath upon them.
#Text=Stop the bottles close, and in a week the Meath will be ready to drink.
#Text=SIR BAYNAM THROCKMORTON  '  S MEATHE.
#Text=Take four quarts of Honey, good measure; put to it four Gallons of water,
#Text=let it stand all night, but stir it well, when you put it together.
#Text=The
#Text= next day boil it, and put to it Nutmegs, Cloves, Mace and Ginger, of each
#Text= half an ounce.
#Text=Let these boil with the honey and water till it will bear an
#Text= Egge at the top without sinking; and then it is enough, if you see the Egge
#Text= the breadth of a sixpence.
#Text=The next day put it in your vessel, and put
#Text= thereto two or three spoonfuls of barm; and when it hath done working, you
#Text= may (if you like it) put in a little Ambergreece in a clout with a stone to
#Text= it to make it sink.
#Text=This should be kept a whole year before it be drunk; it
#Text= will drink much the better, free from any tast of the honey, and then it
#Text= will look as clear as Sack.
#Text=Make it not till Michaelmas, and set it in a
#Text= cool place.
#Text=You may drink it a quarter old, but it will not taste so
#Text= pleasant then, as when it is old.
#Text=TO MAKE WHITE METHEGLIN
#Text=
#Text= Take a Gallon of Honey; put to it four Gallons of water; stir them well
#Text= together, and boil them in a Kettle, till a Gallon be wasted with boiling
#Text= and scumming.
#Text=Then put it into a vessel to cool.
#Text=When it is almost as cold
#Text= as Ale-wort, then clear it out into another vessel: Then put Barm upon it,
#Text=as you do to your Ale, and so let it work.
#Text=And then Tun it up into a
#Text= vessel, and put into it a bag with Ginger, Cloves, and Cinamon bruised a
#Text= little, and so hang the bag in the vessel, and stop it up very close; and
#Text= when it hath stood a month or six weeks, bottle it up and so drink it.
#Text=You
#Text= may put in a little Limmon-peel into some of your Metheglin, for those that
#Text= like that taste; which most persons do very much.
#Text=A RECEIPT FOR MAKING OF MEATH
#Text=
#Text= Mistress Hebden telleth me, that the way of making Honey-drink in Russia,
#Text= is thus; Take for example, 100 Gallons of Spring water, boil it a little;
#Text= then let it stand 24 hours to cool, and much sediment will fall to the
#Text= bottom; from which pour the clear, and warm it, and put 20 or 25 Gallons of
#Text= pure honey to it, and lade it a long time with a great woodden battle-dore,
#Text= till it be well dissolved.
#Text=The next day boil it gently, till you have
#Text= skimed off all the scum that will rise, and that it beareth an Egge boyant.
#Text=And in this Liquor you must put, in the due time, a little quantity of
#Text= Hops, about two handfuls, which must boil sufficiently in the Liquor.
#Text=Put
#Text= this into the cooling fat to cool two or three days.
#Text=When it is about
#Text=milk-warm, take white-bread and cut it into tosts, upon which, (when they
#Text= are hot) spread moderately thick some fresh sweet Ale-yest; and cover the
#Text= superficies of the Liquor with such tosts; Then cover the Tub or Fat with a
#Text= double course sheet, and a blancket or two, which tye fast about it.
#Text=This
#Text= will make your Liquor work up highly.
#Text=When you find it is near it  '  s height
#Text= of working, and that the Liquor is risen to the top of the Tub (of which it
#Text= wanted 8 or 10 Inches at first,) Skim off the tosts and yest, and Tun it up
#Text= in a hogshead: which stop close; but after 24 hours draw it into another
#Text= barrel: for it will leave a great deal of sediment.
#Text=It will work again in
#Text= this second barrel.
#Text=After other 24 hours draw it into another barrel, and
#Text= then it will be clear and pale like White-wine.
#Text=Stop it up close, hanging a
#Text= bag of bruised spice in the bung; and after five or six months, it will be
#Text= fit to drink.
#Text=If you would have your Meath taste of Raspes, or Cherries
#Text= (Morello, sharp Cherries, are the best) prepare the water first with them;
#Text= by putting five or six Gallons of either of these fruits, or more, into
#Text= this proportion of water; in which bruise them to have all their juyce: but
#Text= strain the Liquor from the Grains or Seeds, or Stones.
#Text=And then proceed
#Text= with this tincted water, as is said above.
#Text=You may make your Liquor as
#Text= strong, as you like, of the fruit.
#Text=Cardamon-seeds mingled with the
#Text= suspended spices, adde much to the pleasantness of the drink.
#Text=Limon-peel,
#Text=it in a Rundlet by it self.)
#Text=Then take some very strong firm Paper, and wet
#Text= it on one side with some of the barm that works out, and lay that side over
#Text= the bung to cover it close.
#Text=The barm will make it stick fast to the
#Text= hogshead.
#Text=This covering will serve for a moneth or two.
#Text=Then stop it close
#Text= with strong Cork fitted to the hole, with a linnen about it, to press it
#Text= fast in: But let a little vent with a peg in it be made in hogshead, in
#Text= some fit place above.
#Text=This may be fit to broach in five or six moneths; but
#Text= three weeks or a moneth before you do so, put into each hogshead half an
#Text= ounce of Cinnamon; and two ounces of Cloves beaten into most subtile
#Text= powder.
#Text=(Sometimes he leaves out the Cloves) which will give it a most
#Text= pleasant flavor; and they (as the Ginger did) sink down to the bottome and
#Text= never trouble the Liquor.
#Text=If they be put in long before (much more if they
#Text= be boiled) they loose all their taste and Spirits entirely.
#Text=This will last
#Text= very well half a year drawing.
#Text=But if you stay broaching it a year, and
#Text= then draw it into bottles, it will keep admirable good three or four years,
#Text= growing to be much better, then when broached at six months end.
#Text=It will be
#Text= purer, if you first boil the water by it self, then let it settle 24 hours;
#Text= and pour the clear from the earthy sediment, which will be great, and
#Text= dissolve your honey in that.
#Text=You may Aromatise it with Ambergreece or Musk,
#Text= or both (if you like them) by dissolving a very few Pastils in a Runlet of
#Text=the Barrel as long as it will; then stop it up close for a few days more,
#Text= that so it may clear it self well, and separate and precipitate the dregs.
#Text=Then draw the clear into bottles.
#Text=This will make it less windy, but also a
#Text= little less quick, though more wholesome.
#Text=You may also boil a little
#Text= handful of tops of Rosemary in the Liquor, which giveth it a fine taste:
#Text= but all other herbs, and particularly Sweet-marjoram and Thyme, give it a
#Text= Physical taste.
#Text=A little Limon-peel giveth it a very fine taste.
#Text=If you Tun
#Text= it in a barrel, to work there, you may hang the Ginger and Limon-peel in it
#Text= in a bag, till you bottle it, or till it have done working.
#Text=Then you may
#Text= put two or three stoned and sliced Raisins, and a lump of fine Sugar into
#Text= every bottle to make it quick.
#Text=TO MAKE METHEGLIN
#Text=
#Text= Take five Gallons of water, and one Gallon of good White-honey; set it on
#Text= the fire together, and boil it very well, and skim it very clean; Then take
#Text= it off the fire, and set it by.
#Text=Take six ounces of good Ginger, and two
#Text= ounces of Cinamon, one Ounce of Nutmegs; bruise all these grosly, and put
#Text= them into your hot Liquor, and cover it close, and so let it stand, till it
#Text=Oat-meal.
#Text=And thus you may have a finer Cream then with hasty boiling.
#Text=AN EXCELLENT AND WHOLESOME WATER-GRUEL WITH WOOD-SORREL AND CURRANTS
#Text=
#Text= Into a Possnet of two quarts of water, besides the due proportion of beaten
#Text= Oat-meal, put two handfuls of Wood-sorrel a little-chopped and bruised, and
#Text= a good quantity of picked and washed currants, tyed loosly in a thin stuff
#Text= bag (as a bolter cloth).
#Text=Boil these very well together, seasoning the
#Text= Composition in due time, with Salt, Nutmeg, Mace, or what else you please,
#Text= as Rosemary &c. when it is sufficiently boiled, strain the Oat-meal, and
#Text= press out all the juyce and humidity of the Currants and Herbs, throwing
#Text= away the insipid husks; and season it with Sugar and Butter; and to each
#Text= Porrenger-ful two spoonfuls of Rhenish-wine and the yolk of an Egg.
#Text=THE QUEENS BARLEY-CREAM
#Text=
#Text= You must make a good barley-water, throwing away the three first waters as
#Text= soon as they boil; which will take up about three quarters of an hour.
#Text=Then
#Text=you boil a large quantity of water with the Barley (which thus prepared
#Text= makes the water no more Red or Russet) during an hours space or more; (that
#Text= it may be strong of the Barley; perle-Barley is best,) towards the latter
#Text= end put in the Pullet flead, and the legs cut off; If it should boil too
#Text= long, the emulsion would taste too fleshy.
#Text=When it is enough, let the broth
#Text= run clear from the Barley and pullet, and beat the Almonds with the broth,
#Text= and strain them from it.
#Text=Then sweeten it with Sugar.
#Text=This is to make at
#Text= least two English quarts of Emulsion.
#Text=I should like to put some pulp of
#Text= Barley, boiled by it self, to strain with the Almond-Milk, and, if you
#Text= will, some Melon seeds.
#Text=You may put some juyce of Limon or Orange to it.
#Text=Also season it with Cinnamon, and make the broth stronger of the flesh.
#Text=The Queens white Potage is made only of the white flesh of Capon beaten
#Text= with good broth and strained, and a little juyce of Limon or Orange; but no
#Text= Almonds.
#Text=PRESSIS NOURISSANT
#Text=
#Text= The Queen Mothers _Pressis_ was thus made.
#Text=Take _un Gigot_ of Mutton, a
#Text=BROTH AND POTAGE
#Text=
#Text= Mounsieur de Bourdeaux used to take a mornings a broth, thus made.
#Text=Make a
#Text= very good broth (so as to gelly, when it is cold), a lean piece of a leg of
#Text= Veal, the Crag-end of a neck of Mutton, and a Pullet, seasoning it with a
#Text= little Salt, Cloves and Pepper to your mind.
#Text=Beat some of it with a handful
#Text= of blanched Almonds and twenty husked-seeds of Citron and strain it to the
#Text= whole; put Sugar to it, and so drink it as an Emulsion.
#Text=Otherwhiles He would make a Potage of the broth, (made without fruit),
#Text= boiling and stewing it with some light-bread.
#Text=PAN COTTO
#Text=
#Text= To make a _Pan Cotto_, as the Cardinals use in Rome, Take much thinner
#Text= broth, made of the fleshes as above (or of Mutton alone) and boil it three
#Text= hours, gently and close covered in _una pignata_, with lumps of fine
#Text= light-bread tosted or dried.
#Text=_Un Pan grattato_ is made the same way with
#Text= fine light-bread grated.
#Text=Season the broth of either lightly with Salt, and
#Text=proportion with Pepper and Salt.
#Text=This is a proportion to make about a Gallon of Pease-porage.
#Text=The quantities
#Text= are set down by guess.
#Text=The Coriander-seeds are as much as you can
#Text= conveniently take in the hollow of your hand.
#Text=You may put in a great good
#Text= Onion or two.
#Text=A pretty deal of Parsley, and if you will, and the season
#Text= afford them, you may add what you like of other Porage herbs, such as they
#Text= use for their Porages in France.
#Text=But if you take the savoury herbs dry, you
#Text= must crumble or beat them to small Powder (as you do the Coriander-seed)
#Text= and if any part of them be too big to pass through the strainer, after
#Text= they have given their taste to the quantity, in boiling a sufficient while
#Text= therein, you put them away with the husks of the Pease.
#Text=The Pint of Pease
#Text= that you reserve whole, is only to show that it is Pease-porage.
#Text=They must
#Text= be of the thickness of ordinary Pease-porage.
#Text=For which these proportions
#Text= will make about a Gallon.
#Text=BROTH FOR SICK AND CONVALESCENT PERSONS
#Text=
#Text= Put a Crag-end of a Neck of Mutton, a Knuckle of Veal, and a Pullet into a
#Text=hot.
#Text=Cover this, and let them stew together gently, not boil; and feed it
#Text= with fresh-broth, still as it needeth; This will make the bread swell much,
#Text= and become like gelly.
#Text=AN EXCELLENT POSSET
#Text=
#Text= Take half a pint of Sack, and as much Rhenish wine, sweeten them to your
#Text= taste with Sugar.
#Text=Beat ten yolks of Eggs, and eight of whites exceeding
#Text= well, first taking out the Cocks-tread, and if you will the skins of the
#Text= yolks; sweeten these also, and pour them to the wine, add a stick or two of
#Text= Cinnamon bruised, set this upon a Chafing-dish to heat strongly, but not to
#Text= boil; but it must begin to thicken.
#Text=In the mean time boil for a quarter of
#Text= an hour three pints of Cream seasoned duly with Sugar and some Cinnamon in
#Text= it.
#Text=Then take it off from boiling, but let it stand near the fire, that it
#Text= may continue scalding-hot whiles the wine is heating.
#Text=When both are as
#Text= scalding-hot as they can be without boiling, pour the Cream into the wine
#Text= from as high as you can.
#Text=When all is in, set it upon the fire to stew for
#Text= 1/8 of an hour.
#Text=Then sprinkle all about the top of it the juyce of a 1/4
#Text= part of a Limon; and if you will, you may strew Powder of Cinnamon and
#Text=Sugar, or Ambergreece upon it.
#Text=PEASE OF THE SEEDY BUDS OF TULIPS
#Text=
#Text= In the Spring (about the beginning of May) the flowry-leaves of Tulips do
#Text= fall away, and there remains within them the end of the stalk, which in
#Text= time will turn to seed.
#Text=Take that seedy end (then very tender) and pick
#Text= from it the little excrescencies about it, and cut it into short pieces,
#Text= and boil them and dress them as you would do Pease; and they will taste
#Text= like Pease, and be very savoury.
#Text=BOILED RICE DRY
#Text=
#Text= The manner of boiling Rice to eat with Butter, is this.
#Text=In a Pipkin pour
#Text= upon it as much water, as will swim a good fingers breadth over it.
#Text=Boil it
#Text= gently, till it be tender, and all the water drunk into the Rice; which may
#Text= be in a quarter of an hour or less.
#Text=Stir it often with a woodden spatule or
#Text= spoon, that it burn not to the bottom: But break it not.
#Text=When it is enough,
#Text=
#Text= TO STEW A BREAST OF VEAL
#Text=
#Text= Take a Breast of Veal half rosted, and put it a stewing with some wine and
#Text= gravy; three or four yolks of Eggs minced small; a pretty quantity of
#Text= Sweet-herbs with an Onion, Anchoves or Limon; stick it either with Thyme
#Text= or Limon-peels, and season it to your liking.
#Text=SAUCE OF HORSE RADISH
#Text=
#Text= Take Roots of Horse-radish scraped clean, and lay them to soak in
#Text= fair-water for an hour.
#Text=Then rasp them upon a Grater, and you shall have
#Text= them all in a tender spungy Pap.
#Text=Put Vinegar to it, and a very little
#Text= Sugar, not so much as to be tasted, but to quicken (by contrariety) the
#Text= taste of the other.
#Text=THE QUEENS HOTCHPOT FROM HER ESCUYER DE CUISINE, MR.
#Text=LA MONTAGUE
#Text=
#Text=The Queen Mothers Hotchpot of Mutton, is thus made.
#Text=It is exceeding good of
#Text= fresh Beef also, for those whose Stomacks can digest it.
#Text=Cut a neck of
#Text= Mutton, Crag-end and all into steaks (which you may beat, if you will; but
#Text= they will be very tender without beating) and in the mean time prepare your
#Text= water to boil in a Possnet, (which must be of a convenient bigness to have
#Text= water enough, to cover the meat, and serve all the stewing it, without
#Text= needing to add any more to it; and yet no superfluous water at last.)
#Text=Put
#Text= your meat into the boiling water, and when you have scummed it clean, put
#Text= into it a good handful of Parsley, and as much of Sibboulets (young Onions
#Text= or Sives) chopped small, if you like to eat them in substance; otherwise
#Text= tied up in a bouquet, to throw them away, when they have communicated to
#Text= the water all their taste; some Pepper; three or four Cloves, and a little
#Text= Salt, and half a Limon first pared.
#Text=These must stew or boil simpringly,
#Text= (covered) at least three or four hours (a good deal more, if Beef)
#Text= stirring it often, that it burn not too.
#Text=A good hour before you intend to
#Text= take it off, put some quartered Turneps to it, or, if you like them, some
#Text= Carrots.
#Text=A while after, take a good lump of Houshold-bread, bigger than
#Text= your fist, crust and crum, broil it upon a Gridiron, that it be throughly
#Text= rosted; scrape off the black burning on the on side; then soak it throughly
#Text= in Vinegar, and put this lump of tost into your possnet to stew with it;
#Text=which you take out and throw away after a while.
#Text=About a quarter of an hour
#Text= before you serve it up melt a good lump of Butter (as much as a great Egg)
#Text= till it grow red; then take it from the fire, and put to it a little fine
#Text= flower to thicken it (about a couple of spoonfuls) like thick Pap.
#Text=Stir
#Text= them very well together; then set them on the fire again, till it grow-red,
#Text= stirring it all the while; then put to it a ladleful of the liquor of the
#Text= pot, and let them stew a while together to incorporate, stirring it always.
#Text=Then pour this to the whole substance in the Possnet, to Incorporate with
#Text= all the liquor, and so let them stew a while together.
#Text=Then pour it out of
#Text= the possnet into your dish, meat and all: for it will be so tender, it will
#Text= not endure taking up piece by piece with your hand.
#Text=If you find the taste
#Text= not quick enough, put into it the juyce of the half Limon, you reserved.
#Text=For I should have said, that when you put in the Herbs, you squeese in also
#Text= the juyce of half a Limon (pared from the yellow rinde, which else would
#Text= make it bitter) and throw the pared and squeesed half (the substance) into
#Text= it afterwards.
#Text=The last things (of Butter, bread, flower) cause the
#Text= liaison and thickening of the liquor.
#Text=If this should not be enough, you may
#Text= also put a little gravy of Mutton into it; stirring it well when it is in,
#Text= least it curdle in stewing, or you may put the yolk of an Egg or two to
#Text= your liaison of Butter, Flower, and ladleful of broth.
#Text=For gravy of Mutton.
#Text=pierced into the heart by the water, and grown tender.)
#Text=Then put it to boil
#Text= very gently, (and with no more water, then well to cover it, which you must
#Text= supply with new hot water as it consumeth) for six or seven hours at least,
#Text= that it may be very tender and loose and swelled up.
#Text=Then press and drain
#Text= out all the water from it; and heat it again in a dish, with store of
#Text= melted Butter thickened; and if you like it, you may season it also with
#Text= Pepper and Mustard.
#Text=But it will be yet better, if after it is well and
#Text= tender boiled in water, and that you have pressed all the water you can out
#Text= of it, you boil it again an hour longer in Milk; out of which when you take
#Text= it, to put it into the dish with butter, you do not industriously press out
#Text= all the Milk, as you did the water, but only drain it out gently, pressing
#Text= it moderately.
#Text=In the stewing it with butter, season it to your taste,
#Text= with what you think fitting.
#Text=ANOTHER WAY TO DRESS STOCK-FISH
#Text=
#Text= Beat it exceeding well with a large woodden Mallet, till you may easily
#Text= pluck it all in pieces, severing every flake from other, and every one of
#Text= them in it so being loose, spungy and limber, as the whole fish must be,
#Text=and plyant like a glove, which will be in less then an hour.
#Text=Pull then the
#Text= bones out, and throw them away, and pluck off the skin (as whole as you
#Text= can; but it will have many breaches and holes in it, by the beating) then
#Text= gather all the fish together, and lap it in the skin as well as you can,
#Text= into a round lump, like a bag-pudding, and tye it about with cords or
#Text= strings (like a little Collar of Brawn, or souced fish) and so put it into
#Text= lukewarm water (overnight) to soak, covering the vessel close; but you need
#Text= not keep it near any heat whiles it lyeth soaking.
#Text=Next morning take it out
#Text= that water and vessel, and put it into another, with a moderate quantity of
#Text= other water, to boil; which it must do very leisurely, and but simpringly.
#Text=The main care must be, that the vessel it boileth in, be covered so
#Text= exceeding close, that not the least breath of steam get out, else it will
#Text= not be tender, but tough and hard.
#Text=It will be boiled enough, and become
#Text= very tender in about a good half hour.
#Text=Then take it out, unty it, and throw
#Text= away the skin, and lay the flaky fish in a Cullender, to drain away the
#Text= water from it.
#Text=You must presently throw a little Salt upon it, and all
#Text= about in it, to season it.
#Text=For then it will imbibe it into it self
#Text= presently; whereas if you Salt it not, till it grow cold in the air, it
#Text= will not take it in.
#Text=Mean while prepare your sauce of melted well thickened
#Text= butter (which you may heighten with shreded Onions or Syves, or what well
#Text=tasted herbs you please) and if you will, you may first strew upon the fish
#Text= some very small shreded young Onions, or Sibbouls, or Syves, or Parsley.
#Text=Then upon that pour the melted butter to cover the fish all over, and soak
#Text= into it.
#Text=Serve it in warm and covered.
#Text=TO DRESS PARSNEPS
#Text=
#Text= Scrape well three or four good large roots, cleansing well their outside,
#Text= and cutting off as much of the little end as is Fibrous, and of the great
#Text= end as is hard.
#Text=Put them into a possnet or pot, with about a quart of Milk
#Text= upon them, or as much as will cover them in boiling, which do moderately,
#Text= till you find they are very tender.
#Text=This may be in an hour and half, sooner
#Text= or later, as the roots are of a good kind.
#Text=Then take them out, and scrape
#Text= all the outside into a pulpe, like the pulpe of roasted apples, which put
#Text= in a dish upon a chafing dish of Coals, with a little of the Milk, you
#Text= boiled them in, put to them; not so much as to drown them, but only to
#Text= imbibe them: and then with stewing, the pulpe will imbibe all that Milk.
#Text=When you see it is drunk in, put to the pulpe a little more of the same
#Text= Milk, and stew that, till it be drunk in.
#Text=Continue doing thus till it hath
#Text=drunk in a good quantity of the Milk, and is well swelled with it, and will
#Text= take in no more, which may be in a good half hour.
#Text=Eat them so, without
#Text= Sugar or Butter; for they will have a natural sweetness, that is beyond
#Text= sugar, and will be Unctuous, so as not to need Butter.
#Text=Parsneps (raw) cut into little pieces, is the best food for tame Rabets,
#Text= and makes them sweet.
#Text=As Rice (raw) is for tame Pigeons, and they like it
#Text= best, varying it sometimes with right tares, and other seeds.
#Text=CREAM WITH RICE
#Text=
#Text= A very good Cream to eat hot, is thus made.
#Text=Into a quart of sweet Cream,
#Text= put a spoonful of very fine powder of Rice, and boil them together
#Text= sufficiently, adding Cinnamon, or Mace and Nutmeg to your liking.
#Text=When it
#Text= is boiled enough take it from the fire, and beat a couple of yolks of
#Text= new-laid Eggs, to colour it yellow.
#Text=Sweeten it to your taste.
#Text=Put bread to
#Text= it, in it  '  s due time.
#Text=GREWEL OF OAT-MEAL AND RICE
#Text=
#Text= Doctor Pridion ordered my Lord Cornwallis, for his chief diet in his
#Text= looseness, the following grewel, which he found very tastefull.
#Text=Take about two parts of Oat-meal well beaten in a Mortar, and one part of
#Text= Rice in subtile powder.
#Text=Boil these well in water, as you make water-grewel,
#Text= adding a good proportion of Cinnamon to boil also in due time, then strain
#Text= it through a cloth, and sweeten it to your taste.
#Text=The yolk of an Egg beaten with a little Sherry-sack, and put to it, is not
#Text= bad in a looseness.
#Text=At other times you may add Butter.
#Text=It is very tasteful
#Text= and nourishing.
#Text=SAUCE FOR A CARP OR PIKE.
#Text=TO BUTTER PEASE
#Text=
#Text= Take two or three spoonfuls of the Liquor the Carp was boiled in, and put
#Text= it into a pipkin; There must be no more, then even to cover the bottom of
#Text= the pipkin.
#Text=Make this boil by itself; as soon as it doth so, put to this
#Text=half a pound of sweet butter, let it melt gently, or suddenly, it imports
#Text= not, so as the liquor boiled, when you did put the butter in; when the
#Text= butter is melted, then take it from the fire, and holding the handle in
#Text= your hand, shake it round a good while and strongly, and it will come to be
#Text= thick, that you may almost cut it with a Knife.
#Text=Then squeese juyce of Limon
#Text= into it, or of sharp Orange, or Verjuyce or Vinegar; and heat it again as
#Text= much as you please upon the fire.
#Text=It will ever after continue thick, and
#Text= never again, upon any heating, grow oily, though it be cold and heated
#Text= again twenty times.
#Text=Butter done with fair water, as is said above, with the
#Text= other Liquor, will be thick in the same manner, (for the liquors make no
#Text= difference in that:)
#Text=
#Text= Put of this butter to boiled Pease in their dish, which cover with another;
#Text= so shake them very strongly, and a good while together.
#Text=This is by much the
#Text= best way to butter pease, and not to let the butter melt in the middle of
#Text= them, and then stir them long with a spoon.
#Text=This will grow Oily (though it
#Text= be good at the first doing) if you heat them again: The other, never; and
#Text= therefore, is the best way upon all occasions to make such thickened melted
#Text= Butter.
#Text=You may make sauce for a Pike in the same manner you did for a
#Text= Carpe; putting Horse-radish to it if you please.
#Text=A HERRING-PYE
#Text=
#Text= Put great store of sliced Onions, with Currants and Raisins of the Sun both
#Text= above and under the Herrings, and store of Butter, and so bake them.
#Text=A SYLLABUB
#Text=
#Text= Take a reasonable quantity (as about half a Porrenger full) of the Syrup,
#Text= that hath served in the making of dryed plums; and into a large
#Text= Syllabub-pot milk or squirt, or let fall from high a sufficient quantity of
#Text= Milk or Cream.
#Text=This Syrup is very quick of the fruit, and very weak of
#Text= Sugar; and therefore makes the Syllabub exceeding well tasted.
#Text=You may also
#Text= use the Syrup used in the like manner in the drying of Cherries.
#Text=BUTTER AND OIL TO FRY FISH
#Text=
#Text=The best Liquor to fry Fish in, is to take Butter and Salet Oyl, first well
#Text= clarified together.
#Text=This hath not the unsavoury taste of Oyl alone, nor the
#Text= blackness of Butter alone.
#Text=It fryeth Fish crisp, yellow, and well tasted.
#Text=TO PREPARE SHRIMPS FOR DRESSING
#Text=
#Text= When you will Butter Shrimps, first wash them well in warm Milk and Water
#Text= equally mingled together, and let them soak a little in it; then wash them
#Text= again in fresh Milk and Water warmed, letting them also soak therein a
#Text= while.
#Text=Do this twice or thrice with fresh Milk and Water.
#Text=This will take
#Text= away all the rankness and slimyness of them.
#Text=Then Butter them, or prepare
#Text= them for the table, as you think fit.
#Text=TOSTS OF VEAL
#Text=
#Text= My Lady Lusson makes thus her plain tosts of kidney of Veal: Cut the kidney
#Text= with all the fat about it, and a good piece of the lean flesh besides.
#Text=Hash
#Text= all this as small as you can.
#Text=Put to it a quarter of a pound of picked and
#Text=washed Currants, and as much Sugar, one Nutmeg grated, four yolks and two
#Text= whites of new-laid Eggs raw; work all these very well together, seasoning
#Text= it with Salt.
#Text=Spread it thick upon slices of light white-bread cut like
#Text= tosts.
#Text=Then fry them in Butter, such quantity as may boil over the tops of
#Text= the tosts.
#Text=TO MAKE MUSTARD
#Text=
#Text= The best way of making Mustard is this: Take of the best Mustard-seed
#Text= (which is black) for example a quart.
#Text=Dry it gently in an oven, and beat it
#Text= to subtle powder, and searse it.
#Text=Then mingle well strong Wine-vinegar with
#Text= it, so much that it be pretty liquid, for it will dry with keeping.
#Text=Put to
#Text= this a little Pepper beaten small (white is the best) at discretion, as
#Text= about a good pugil, and put a good spoonful of Sugar to it (which is not to
#Text= make it taste sweet, but rather quick, and to help the fermentation) lay a
#Text= good Onion in the bottom, quartered if you will, and a Race of Ginger
#Text= scraped and bruised; and stir it often with a Horse-radish root cleansed,
#Text= which let always lie in the pot, till it have lost it  '  s vertue, then take a
#Text= new one.
#Text=This will keep long, and grow better for a while.
#Text=It is not good
#Text=till after a month, that it have fermented a while.
#Text=Some think it will be the quicker, if the seed be ground with fair water,
#Text= in stead of vinegar, putting store of Onions in it.
#Text=My Lady Holmeby makes her quick fine Mustard thus: Choose true
#Text= Mustard-seed; dry it in an oven, after the bread is out.
#Text=Beat and searse it
#Text= to a most subtle powder.
#Text=Mingle Sherry-sack with it (stirring it a long
#Text= time very well, so much as to have it of a fit consistence for Mustard.
#Text=Then put a good quantity of fine Sugar to it, as five or six spoonfuls, or
#Text= more, to a pint of Mustard.
#Text=Stir and incorporate all well together.
#Text=This
#Text= will keep good a long time.
#Text=Some do like to put to it a little (but a
#Text= little) of very sharp Wine-vinegar.
#Text=TO MAKE A WHITE-POT
#Text=
#Text= Boil three pints of sweet Cream with a very little Salt and some sliced
#Text= Nutmeg.
#Text=As soon as it begins to boil, take it from the fire.
#Text=In the mean
#Text= time beat the yolks of twelve or fifteen new-laid Eggs very well with some
#Text=Rose or Orange-flower-water, and sweeten the Cream to your taste with
#Text= Sugar.
#Text=Then beat three or four spoonfuls of Cream with them, and quickly as
#Text= many more; so proceeding, till you have incorporated all the Cream and all
#Text= the Eggs.
#Text=Then pour the Eggs and Cream into a deep dish laid over with
#Text= sippets of fine light bread, which will rise up to the top for the most
#Text= part.
#Text=When it is cooled and thickened enough to bear Raisins of the Sun,
#Text= strew all over the top with them (well-washed.)
#Text=Then press a little way
#Text= into it with great lumps of raw Marrow.
#Text=Two bones will suffice.
#Text=Cover your
#Text= dish with another, and set it upon a great pot of boiling water, with a
#Text= good space between the water and the dish, that there be room for the hot
#Text= steam to rise and strike upon the dish.
#Text=Keep good fire always under your
#Text= pot.
#Text=In less then an hour (usually) it is baked enough.
#Text=You will perceive
#Text= that, if the Marrow look brown, and be enough baked.
#Text=If it should continue
#Text= longer on the heat, it would melt.
#Text=You may bake it in an oven if you will;
#Text= but it is hard to regulate it so, that it be not too much or too little:
#Text= whereas the boiling water is certain.
#Text=You may strew Ambred Sugar upon it,
#Text= either before you set it to bake, or after it is done.
#Text=FOR ROSTING OF MEAT
#Text=
#Text= To rost fine meat (as Partridge, Pheasant, Chicken, Pigeon) that it be full
#Text= of juyce; baste it as soon as it is through hot, and time to baste, with
#Text= Butter.
#Text=When it is very moist all over, sprinkle flower upon it every
#Text= where, that by turning about the fire, it may become a thin crust.
#Text=Then
#Text= baste it no more till the latter end.
#Text=This crust will keep in all the
#Text= juyce.
#Text=A little before you take it up, baste it again with Butter, and this
#Text= will melt away all the crust.
#Text=Then give it three or four turns of the spit,
#Text= that it may make the outside yellow and crisp.
#Text=You may also baste such meat with yolks of new-laid Eggs, beaten into a
#Text= thin oyl.
#Text=But with this you continue basting all the while the meat
#Text= rosteth.
#Text=TO STEW A RUMP OF BEEF
#Text=
#Text= Take a rump of Beef, break all the bones; season it with Pepper and Salt to
#Text= your liking; Take three or four Nutmegs, and a quantity of Mace, beat them
#Text= grossly; Then take a bunch of very good sweet herbs, and one good Onion cut
#Text=in quarters, or Garlike, as you like it.
#Text=Put in half a pint of White-wine
#Text= Vinegar, and one pint of good Claret, one handful of Sugar; and a piece or
#Text= two of beef Suet or Butter: shred some Cabbage under and over, and scrape
#Text= in a pound of good old Cheese.
#Text=Put all these into an earthen pot, and let
#Text= it stand in an oven with brown-bread four or five hours; but let the pot be
#Text= covered close with paste.
#Text=TO STEW A RUMP OF BEEF
#Text=
#Text= Take a fat rump of young Beef, as it comes from the Butcher, and take out
#Text= all the bones, excepting the tip of it towards the tail that is all fat,
#Text= which you cannot take out, without spoiling or defacing or breaking it.
#Text=But
#Text= take out all the thick bones towards the Chine, and the thick Sinews, that
#Text= are on the outer sides of the flesh; (which will never become tender with
#Text= boiling) so that you have nothing but the pure flesh and fat, without any
#Text= bony or tough substance.
#Text=Then beat well the lean part with a woodden roling
#Text= pin, and when you have beaten well one side, turn the other.
#Text=Then rub it
#Text= well with Pepper grosly beaten, and salt; just as you would do, to season a
#Text= Venison pasty, making the seasoning higher or gentler according to your
#Text=taste.
#Text=Then lay it in a fit vessel, with a flat bottom (pipkin or kettle as
#Text= you have conveniency) that will but just contain it, but so that it may lye
#Text= at ease.
#Text=Or you may tye it up in a loose thin linnen cloth, or boulter, as
#Text= they do Capons _à la mode_, or Brawn, or the like.
#Text=Then put water upon it,
#Text= but just to cover it, and boil it close covered a matter of two hours
#Text= pretty smartly, so that it be well half boiled.
#Text=Then take it out of that,
#Text= and put it into another fit vessel, or the same cleansed, and put upon it
#Text= about two quarts of good strong deep well bodied Claret-wine, and a good
#Text= bundle of sweet-herbs, (Penny-royal, Sweet-Marjoram, Winter-savory, Limon
#Text= Thyme, &c.) and a good large Onion peeled, and stuck as close with Cloves,
#Text= as you can stick it, if you like the taste of Onions.
#Text=They must be the
#Text= strong biting Onions, that are round and red: a little Nutmeg, and some
#Text= Mace.
#Text=Put to the wine about a pint of the Liquor that you have already
#Text= boiled the Beef in; and if you would have it strong of the seasoning of
#Text= Pepper, and Salt; take the bottom of this Liquor.
#Text=Thus let it boil very
#Text= gently, simpringly, or rather stew with Char-coal over a little furnace, or
#Text= a fit Chafing-dish, a matter of three hours, close covered.
#Text=If the Liquor
#Text= waste too much, you may recruit it with what you have kept of that, which
#Text= your beef was boiled in.
#Text=When it is near time to take it up, stew some
#Text= Oysters in their own Liquor (to which you may add at the latter end, some
#Text=drained from all moisture: put them into the Liquor (with all the
#Text= Ingredients in it) which you must be sure, be enough to cover them.
#Text=In ten
#Text= or twelve days, they will have taken into them the full taste of the
#Text= pickle, and will keep very good half a year.
#Text=If you have much supernatant
#Text= Liquor, you may parboil more Mushrooms next day, and put them to the first.
#Text=If you have not gathered at once enough for a dressing, you may keep them
#Text= all night in water to preserve them white, and gather more the next day, to
#Text= joyn to them.
#Text=TO STEW WARDENS OR PEARS
#Text=
#Text= Pare them, put them into a Pipkin, with so much Red or Claret Wine and
#Text= water, _ana_, as will near reach to the top of the Pears.
#Text=Stew or boil
#Text= gently, till they grow tender, which may be in two hours.
#Text=After a while,
#Text= put in some sticks of Cinnamon bruised and a few Cloves.
#Text=When they are
#Text= almost done, put in Sugar enough to season them well and their Syrup, which
#Text= you pour out upon them in a deep Plate.
#Text=TO STEW APPLES
#Text=
#Text= Pare them and cut them into slices.
#Text=Stew them with Wine and Water as the
#Text= Pears, and season them in like manner with Spice.
#Text=Towards the end sweeten
#Text= them with Sugar, breaking the Apples into Pap by stirring them.
#Text=When you
#Text= are ready to take them off, put in good store of fresh-butter, and
#Text= incorporate it well with them, by stirring them together.
#Text=You stew these
#Text= between two dishes.
#Text=The quickest Apples are the best.
#Text=PORTUGUEZ EGGS
#Text=
#Text= The way that the Countess de Penalva makes the Portuguez Eggs for the
#Text= Queen, is this.
#Text=Take the yolks (clean picked from the whites and germ) of
#Text= twelve new-laid Eggs.
#Text=Beat them exceedingly with a little (scarce a
#Text= spoonful) of Orange-flower-water.
#Text=When they are exceeding liquid, clear,
#Text= and uniformly a thin Liquor, put to them one pound of pure double refined
#Text= Sugar (if it be not so pure, it must be clarified before) and stew them in
#Text= your dish or bason over a very gentle fire, stirring them continually,
#Text= whiles they are over it, so that the whole may become one uniform
#Text=substance, of the consistence of an Electuary (beware they grow not too
#Text= hard; for without much caution and attention, that will happen on a sudden)
#Text= which then you may eat presently, or put into pots to keep.
#Text=You may
#Text= dissolve Ambergreece (if you will, ground first very much with Sugar) in
#Text= Orange-flower or Rose-water, before hand, and put it (warm and dissolved)
#Text= to the Eggs, when you set them to stew.
#Text=If you clarifie your Sugar, do it
#Text= with one of these waters, and whites of Eggs.
#Text=The flavor of these
#Text= sweet-waters goeth almost all away with boiling.
#Text=Therefore half a spoonful
#Text= put into the composition, when you take it from the fire, seasoneth it more
#Text= then ten times as much, put in at the first.
#Text=TO BOIL EGGS
#Text=
#Text= A certain and infallible method to boil new-laid Eggs to sup up, and yet
#Text= that they have the white turned to milk, is thus: Break a very little hole,
#Text= at the bigger end of the shell, and put it into the water, whiles it
#Text= boileth.
#Text=Let it remain boiling, whiles your Pulse beateth two hundred
#Text= stroaks.
#Text=Then take it out immediately, and you will find it of an exact
#Text= temper: others put Eggs into boyling water just as you take it from the
#Text=fire, and let them remain there, till the water be so cooled, that you may
#Text= just put in your hand, and take out the Eggs.
#Text=Others put the Eggs into cold water, which they set upon the fire, and as
#Text= soon as the water begins to boil, the Eggs are enough.
#Text=TO MAKE CLEAR GELLY OF BRAN
#Text=
#Text= Take two pound of the broadest open Bran of the best Wheat, and put it to
#Text= infuse in a Gallon of Water, during two or three days, that the water may
#Text= soak into the pure flower, that sticks to the bran.
#Text=Then boil it three or
#Text= four walms, and presently take it from the fire, and strain it through some
#Text= fine strainer.
#Text=A milky substance will come out, which let stand to settle
#Text= about half a day.
#Text=Pour off the clear water, that swimmeth over the starch
#Text= or flomery, that is in the bottom (which is very good for Pap, &c.) and
#Text= boil it up to a gelly, as you do Harts-horn gelly or the like, and season
#Text= it to your taste.
#Text=peeled and quartered, and two bay-leaves, before you put them into the
#Text= oven.
#Text=Before they are set in, you do not fill them with water to the top,
#Text= least any should spill in sliding them in; but fill them up by a bowl
#Text= fastned to a long Pole.
#Text=No water must be put in, after the oven is closed
#Text= (nor the oven ever be opened, till after all is throughly baked) and
#Text= therefore you must put in enough at first to serve to the last; you must
#Text= rowl your Collars as close as may be, that no air may be left in the folds
#Text= of them: and sow them up in exceeding strong cloth, which a strong man must
#Text= pull as hard as He can in the sowing.
#Text=Their cloths must not be pulled off,
#Text= till the Collars have been three or four days out of the oven, least you
#Text= pull off part of the Brawn with them.
#Text=You may put the same proportion of
#Text= Pepper, Cloves, &c. into the Souce drink as you did in the baking them;
#Text= which at either time (especially at first) give them a fine taste.
#Text=The
#Text= Souce-drink is made of six shillings Beer, and Thames or River-water, of
#Text= each an equal quantity, well boiled with Salt.
#Text=When boiled and cold, put in
#Text= to it two or three quarts of skimmed Milk, only to colour it; and so change
#Text= it once in three Weeks.
#Text=Tender Brawn sliced thin, and laid Sallet-wise in a
#Text= dish as the sliced Capon, and seasoned with Pepper, Salt and Vinegar and
#Text= Oyl, with a little Limon, is a very good Sallet.
#Text=SALLET OF COLD CAPON ROSTED
#Text=
#Text= It is a good Sallet, to slice a cold Capon thin; mingle with it some
#Text= Sibbolds, Lettice, Rocket and Tarragon sliced small.
#Text=Season all with
#Text= Pepper, Salt, Vinegar and Oyl, and sliced Limon.
#Text=A little Origanum doth
#Text= well with it.
#Text=MUTTON BAKED LIKE VENISON, SOAKING EITHER IN THEIR BLOOD
#Text=
#Text= Take a large fat loin of Mutton (or two) boned after the manner of Venison.
#Text=Season it well to your taste with Pepper and Salt.
#Text=Then lay it to steep all
#Text= night in enough of the sheep  '  s blood, to cover it over, and soak well into
#Text= it.
#Text=Then lay it into the past, with all the clotted thick blood, under it,
#Text= upon it, and hanging about it.
#Text=You may season the blood with Pepper and
#Text= Salt, before you lay the meat in it.
#Text=But though you do not, it will not be
#Text= amiss, so as the meat be seasoned high enough.
#Text=Then bake it as you do an
#Text= ordinary Pasty; and you may put gravy of Mutton or strong broth into it.
#Text=You may do it in a dish with past; as My Lady of Newport doth Her Venison.
#Text=This way of steeping in blood before you bake it, is very good also for
#Text= Venison.
#Text=TO MAKE AN EXCELLENT HARE-PYE
#Text=
#Text= Hash the flesh of as many Hares, as you please, very small.
#Text=Then beat them
#Text= strongly in a Mortar into a Paste, which season duly with Pepper and Salt.
#Text=Lard it throughly all over with great Lardons of Lard well rowled in Pepper
#Text= and Salt.
#Text=Put this into a straight earthen pot, to lye close in it.
#Text=If you
#Text= like Onions, you may put one or two quartered into the bottom of the Pot.
#Text=Put store of Sweet-butter upon the meat, and upon that, some strong red
#Text= Claret-wine.
#Text=Cover the pot with a double strong brown paper, tyed close
#Text= about the mouth of it.
#Text=Set it to bake with houshold-bread (or in an oven,
#Text= as a Venison pasty) for eight or ten hours.
#Text=Then take out the pot, and
#Text= thence the meat, and pour away all the Liquor, which let settle.
#Text=Then take
#Text= all the congealed Butter, and clarifie it well.
#Text=Put your meat again into
#Text= the pot, and put upon it your clarified Butter, and as much more as is
#Text= necessary.
#Text=And I believe the putting of Claret-wine to it now is better,
#Text= and to omit it before.
#Text=Bake it again, but a less while.
#Text=Pour out all the
#Text=Liquor, when it is baked, and clarifie the Butter again, and pour it upon
#Text= the meat, and so let it cool; The Butter must be at least two or three
#Text= fingers breadth over the meat.
#Text=TO BAKE BEEF
#Text=
#Text= Bone it, and beat it exceeding well on all sides, with a roling pin, upon a
#Text= table.
#Text=Then season it with Pepper and Salt, (rubbing them in very well) and
#Text= some Parsley, and a few Sweet herbs (Penny-royal, Winter-savoury,
#Text= Sweet-marjoram, Limon Thyme, Red-sage, which yet to some seems to have a
#Text= Physical taste) an Onion if you will.
#Text=Squeese it into the pot as close as
#Text= you can.
#Text=Put Butter upon it, and Claret-wine, and covered all as above.
#Text=Bake it in a strong oven eight or ten hours.
#Text=Take it out of the oven, and
#Text= the meat out of the pot, which make clean, from all settlings; and squeese
#Text= all the juyce from it (even by a gentle press.)
#Text=Then put it in again hard
#Text= pressed into the pot.
#Text=Clarifie the Butter, that you poured with the Liquor
#Text= from the meat out of the pot; and pour it again with more flesh, to have
#Text= enough to cover it two or three fingers thick.
#Text=TO BAKE PIDGEONS, (WHICH ARE THUS EXCELLENT, AND WILL KEEP A QUARTER OF A
#Text= YEAR) OR TEALS, OR WILD-DUCKS
#Text=
#Text= Season them duly with Pepper and Salt; then lay them in the pot, and put
#Text= store of Butter, and some Claret-wine to them.
#Text=Cover and bake as above: but
#Text= a less while according to the tenderness of the meat.
#Text=In due time take out
#Text= your pot, and your birds out of it, which press not, but only wipe off the
#Text= Liquor.
#Text=Pour it out all.
#Text=Clarifie the Butter; put in the birds again, and
#Text= the clarified butter, and as much more as needs (all melted) upon them, and
#Text= let it cool.
#Text=You may put a few Bay-leaves upon any of these baked meats,
#Text= between the meat and the Butter.
#Text=GREEN-GEESE-PYE
#Text=
#Text= An excellent cold Pye is thus made.
#Text=Take two fat Green-geese; bone them,
#Text= and lay them in paste one upon the other, seasoning them well with Pepper
#Text= and Salt, and some little Nutmeg, both above and below and between the two
#Text= Geese.
#Text=When it is well-baked and out of the oven, pour in melted Butter at
#Text=Rost wilde Ducks putting into their Bellies some Sage and a little Onion
#Text= (both well shreded) wrought into a lump with butter, adding a little Pepper
#Text= and Salt.
#Text=And let their sauce be a little gravy of Mutton, to enlarge the
#Text= seasoned gravy, that comes from the Ducks when they are cut up.
#Text=TO SOUCE TURKEYS
#Text=
#Text= Take a good fat Turkey or two; dress them clean, and bone them; then tye
#Text= them up in the manner of Sturgeon with some thing clean washed.
#Text=Take your
#Text= kettle, and put into it a pottle of good White-wine, a quart of Water, and
#Text= a quart of Vinegar; make it boil, and season it with Salt pretty well.
#Text=Then
#Text= put in your Turkeys, and let them boil till they be very tender.
#Text=When they
#Text= are enough boiled, take them out, and taste the Liquor; if it be not sharp
#Text= enough, put more Vinegar, and let it boil a little; then put it into an
#Text= earthen pot, that will hold both Turkeys.
#Text=When it is cold enough, and the
#Text= Turkeys through-cold, put them into the Liquor in the Pot, and be sure they
#Text= be quite covered with the Liquor; Let them lye in it three weeks or a
#Text= month; Then serve it to the table, with Fennel on it, and eat it with elder
#Text= Vinegar.
#Text=less Tansey, so little that it may not taste distinctly in the composition.
#Text=The juyce of Limons is put in at the end of all.
#Text=You may lay thin slices of
#Text= Limon upon the Tansey made, and Sugar upon them.
#Text=ANOTHER WAY
#Text=
#Text= Beat twelve Eggs (six whites put away) by themselves exceeding well (two or
#Text= three hours), sometimes putting in a spoonful of Cream to keep them from
#Text= oyling; Then mingle them well with a quart of Cream; to which put about
#Text= half a pint of juyce of Spinage (as much as will make the Cream green) or
#Text= of green wheat, and four spoonfuls of juyce or Tansey, one Nutmeg scraped
#Text= into thin slices, and half a pound of Sugar; All things exceeding well
#Text= Incorporated together; Fry this with fresh butter, no more then to glase
#Text= the Pan over, and keep the Tansey from sticking to the Pan.
#Text=TO MAKE CHEESE-CAKES
#Text=
#Text= Take twelve quarts of Milk warm from the Cow, turn it with a good spoonful
#Text=of Runnet.
#Text=Break it well, and put it into a large strainer, in which rowl
#Text= it up and down, that all the Whey may run out into a little tub; when all
#Text= that will is run out, wring out more.
#Text=Then break the curds well; then wring
#Text= it again, and more whey will come.
#Text=Thus break and wring till no more come.
#Text=Then work the Curds exceedingly with your hand in a tray, till they become
#Text= a short uniform Paste.
#Text=Then put to it the yolks of eight new laid Eggs, and
#Text= two whites, and a pound of butter.
#Text=Work all this long together.
#Text=In the long working (at the several times) consisteth the making them
#Text= good.
#Text=Then season them to your taste with Sugar finely beaten; and put in
#Text= some Cloves and Mace in subtile powder.
#Text=Then lay them thick in Coffins of
#Text= fine Paste, and bake them.
#Text=SHORT AND CRISP CRUST FOR TARTS AND PYES
#Text=
#Text= To half a peck of fine flower, take a pound and half of Butter, in this
#Text= manner.
#Text=Put your Butter with at least three quarts of cold water (it
#Text= imports not how much or how little the water is) into a little kettle to
#Text= melt, and boil gently: as soon as it is melted, scum off the Butter with a
#Text=is thus.
#Text=Have Coops, wherein every fowl is a part, and not room to turn in,
#Text= and means to cleanse daily the ordure behind them, and two troughs; for
#Text= before that, one may be scalding and drying the day the other is used, and
#Text= before every fowl one partition for meat, another for drink.
#Text=All their
#Text= Meat is this: Boil Barley in water, till it be tender, keep some so, and
#Text= another parcel of it boil with Milk, and another with strong Ale.
#Text=Let them
#Text= be boiled as wheat that is creed.
#Text=Use them different days for variety, to
#Text= get the fowl appetite.
#Text=Lay it in their trough, with some Brown-Sugar
#Text= mingled with it.
#Text=In the partition for Liquor, let them have water or strong
#Text= Ale to drink.
#Text=They will be very drunk and sleep; then eat again.
#Text=Let a
#Text= Candle stand all night over the Coop, and then they will eat much of the
#Text= night.
#Text=With this course they will be prodigiously fat in a fortnight.
#Text=Be
#Text= sure to keep them very sweet.
#Text=This maketh the taste pure.
#Text=ANOTHER WAY OF FEEDING CHICKEN
#Text=
#Text= Take Barley meal, and with droppings of small Ale, (or Ale it self) make it
#Text= into a consistence of batter for Pan-cakes.
#Text=Let this be all their food.
#Text=Which put into the troughs before them, renewing it thrice a day, morning,
#Text=noon and evening; making their troughs very clean every time, and keeping
#Text= their Coops always very clean and sweet.
#Text=This is to serve them for drink as
#Text= well as meat, and no other drink be given them.
#Text=Feed them thus six days;
#Text= the seventh give them nothing in their troughs but powder of brick searced,
#Text= which scowreth and cleanseth them much, and makes their flesh exceeding
#Text= white.
#Text=The next day fall to their former food for six days more, and the
#Text= seventh again to powder of Brick.
#Text=Then again to barley Meal and Ale.
#Text=Thus
#Text= they will be exceeding fat in fifteen days, and purely white and sweet.
#Text=TO FATTEN YOUNG CHICKENS IN A WONDERFULL DEGREE
#Text=
#Text= Boil Rice in Milk till it be very tender and Pulpy, as when you make Milk
#Text= Potage.
#Text=It must be thick, almost so thick, that a spoon may stand an-end in
#Text= it.
#Text=Sweeten this very well with ordinary Sugar.
#Text=Put this into their troughs
#Text= where they feed, that they may be always eating of it.
#Text=It must be made
#Text= fresh every day.
#Text=Their drink must be onely Milk, in another little trough
#Text= by their meat-trough.
#Text=Let a candle (fitly disposed) stand by them all
#Text= night; for seeing their meat, they will eat all night long.
#Text=You put the
#Text= Chicken up, as soon as they can feed of themselves; which will be within a
#Text=day or two after they are hatched, and in twelve days, or a fortnight, they
#Text= will be prodigiously fat; but after they have come to their height, they
#Text= will presently fall back.
#Text=Therefore they must be eaten as soon as they are
#Text= come to their height.
#Text=Their Pen or Coop must be contrived so, that the Hen
#Text= (who must be with them, to sit over them) may not go at liberty to eat away
#Text= their meat, but be kept to her own diet, in a part of the Coop that she
#Text= cannot get out of.
#Text=But the Chicken must have liberty to go from her to
#Text= other parts of the Coop, where they may eat their own meat, and come in
#Text= again to the Hen, to be warmed by her, at their pleasure.
#Text=You must be
#Text= careful to keep their Coop very clean.
#Text=TO FEED CHICKEN
#Text=
#Text= Fatten your Chicken the first week with Oatmeal scalded in Milk; the second
#Text= with Rice and Sugar in Milk.
#Text=In a fortnight they will be prodigiously fat.
#Text=It is good to give them sometimes a little Gravel, or powder of Glass, to
#Text= cleanse their maws, and give them appetite.
#Text=If you put a little bran with their meat, it will keep their maws clean,
#Text=and give them appetite.
#Text=ANOTHER EXCELLENT WAY TO FATTEN CHICKEN
#Text=
#Text= Boil white bread in Milk, as though you were to eat it; but make it thick
#Text= of the bread, which is sliced into it in thin slices, not so thick as if it
#Text= were to make a pudding; but so, that when the bread is eaten out, there may
#Text= some liquid milk remain for the Chicken to drink; or that at first you may
#Text= take up some liquid Milk in a spoon, if you industriously avoid the bread:
#Text= sweeten very well this potage with good Kitchin Sugar of six pence a pound;
#Text= so put it into the trough before them.
#Text=Put there but a little at a time,
#Text= (two or three spoonfuls) that you may not clog them, and feed them five
#Text= times a day, between their wakening in the morning, and their roosting at
#Text= night.
#Text=Give them no other drink; the Milk that remaineth after they have
#Text= eaten the bread, is sufficient; neither give them Gravel, or ought else.
#Text=Keep their Coops very clean, as also their troughs, cleansing them very
#Text= well every morning.
#Text=To half a dozen very little Chickens, little bigger
#Text= then black-birds, an ordinary porenger full every day may serve.
#Text=And in
#Text= eight days they will be prodigiously fat, one peny loaf, and less then two
#Text=quarts of Milk and about half a pound of Sugar will serve little ones the
#Text= whole time.
#Text=Bigger Chickens will require more, and two or three days longer
#Text= time.
#Text=When any of them are at their height of fat, you must eat them; for
#Text= if they live longer, they will fall back, and grow lean.
#Text=Be sure to make
#Text= their potage very sweet.
#Text=AN EXCELLENT WAY TO CRAM CHICKEN
#Text=
#Text= Stone a pound of Raisins of the Sun, and beat them in a Mortar to Pulp;
#Text= pour a quart of Milk upon them, and let them soak so all night.
#Text=Next
#Text= morning stir them well together, and put to them so much Crums of Grated
#Text= stale white bread as to bring it to a soft paste, work all well together,
#Text= and lay it in the trough before the Chicken (which must not be above six in
#Text= a pen, and keep it very clean) and let a candle be by them all night.
#Text=The
#Text= delight of this meat will make them eat continually; and they will be so
#Text= fat (when they are but of the bigness of a Black-bird) that they will not
#Text= be able to stand, but lie down upon their bellies to eat.
#Text=TO FEED PARTRIDGES THAT YOU HAVE TAKEN WILDE
#Text=
#Text= You must often change their food, giving them but of one kind at a time,
#Text= that so their appetites may be fresh to the others, when they are weary of
#Text= the present.
#Text=Sometimes dry wheat; Sometimes wheat soaked two or three days
#Text= in water, to make it soft and tender; Sometimes barley so used; Sometimes
#Text= oats in like manner.
#Text=Give them continually to lie by them; Some of the
#Text= great green leaves of Cabbages, that grow at the bottom of the stalk, and
#Text= that are thrown away, when you gather the Cabbage; which you may give them
#Text= either whole or a little chopped.
#Text=Give them often Ants and their Eggs,
#Text= laying near them the inward mould of an Ant hill, taken up with the Ants in
#Text= it.
#Text=TO MAKE PUFFS
#Text=
#Text= Take new milk Curds, strained well from the whey; then rub them very well;
#Text= season them with Nutmeg, Mace, Rose-water and Sugar; then take an Egg or
#Text= two, a good piece of Butter, and a handful of flower; work all together,
#Text= and make them into Balls; bake them in an oven, upon sheets of Paper; when
#Text=they are baked, serve them up with butter melted and beaten with Rose-water
#Text= and Sugar.
#Text=In stead of flower, you may take fine grated-bread, dried very
#Text= well, but not Crisp.
#Text=APPLES IN GELLY
#Text=
#Text= My Lady Paget makes her fine preserved Pippins, thus: They are done best,
#Text= when Pippins are in their prime for quickness, which is in November.
#Text=Make
#Text= your Pippin-water as strong as you can of the Apples, and that it may be
#Text= the less boiled, and consequently the paler, put in at first the greatest
#Text= quantity of pared and quartered Apples, the water will bear.
#Text=To every Pint
#Text= of Pippin-water add (when you put the Sugar to it) a quarter of a pint of
#Text= fair spring-water, that will bear soap (of which sort only you must use)
#Text= and use half a pound of Sugar, the purest double refined.
#Text=If you will have
#Text= much gelly, two Pippins finely pared and whole, will be enough; you may put
#Text= in more, if you will have a greater proportion of substance to the gelly.
#Text=Put at first but half the Sugar to the Liquor; for so it will be the paler.
#Text=Boil the Apples by themselves in fair water, with a very little Sugar, to
#Text= make them tender; then put them into the liquor, and the rest, the other
#Text=half of the Sugar with them.
#Text=Boil them with a quick fire, till they be
#Text= enough, and the liquor do gelly, and that you see the Apples look very
#Text= clear, and as though they were transparent.
#Text=You must put the juyce of two
#Text= Limons and half an Orange to this in the due time.
#Text=Every Pippin should be
#Text= lapped over in a broad-pill of Orange; which you must prepare thus.
#Text=Pare
#Text= your Orange broad and very thin, and all hanging together, rub it with
#Text= Salt, prick it, and boil it in several waters, to take away the bitterness,
#Text= and make it tender.
#Text=Then preserve it by it self with sufficient quantity of
#Text= Sugar.
#Text=When it is throughly done, and very tender (which you must cast to
#Text= do before hand, to be ready when the Apples are ready to be put up) take
#Text= them out of their Syrup, and lap every Pippin in an Orange-peel, and put
#Text= them into a pot or glass, and pour the liquor upon them: which will be
#Text= gelly over and about the Apples, when all is cold.
#Text=This proportion of
#Text= liquor, Apples, and Orange-peels, will take up about three quarters of a
#Text= pound of Sugar in all.
#Text=If you would keep them any time, you must put in
#Text= weight for weight of Sugar.
#Text=I conceive Apple-John  '  s in stead of Pippins will do better, both for the
#Text= gelly and Syrup; especially at the latter end of the year; and I like them
#Text= thin sliced, rather than whole; and the Orange-peels scattered among them

#Text= A FLOMERY-CAUDLE
#Text=
#Text= When Flomery is made and cold, you may make a pleasant and wholesome caudle
#Text= of it, by taking some lumps and spoonfuls of it, and boil it with Ale and
#Text= White wine, then sweeten it to your taste with Sugar.
#Text=There will remain in
#Text= the Caudle some lumps of the congealed flomery, which are not ungrateful.
#Text=PLEASANT CORDIAL TABLETS, WHICH ARE VERY COMFORTING, AND STRENGTHEN NATURE
#Text= MUCH
#Text=
#Text= Take four ounces of blanched Almonds; of Pine kernels, and of Pistachios,
#Text= _ana_, four Ounces.
#Text=Erin-go-roots, Candid-Limon peels, _ana_, three Ounces,
#Text= Candid Orange peels two Ounces, Candid Citron-peels four Ounces, of powder
#Text= of white Amber, as much as will lie upon a shilling; and as much of the
#Text= powder of pearl, 20 grains of Ambergreece, three grains of Musk, a book of
#Text= leaf gold, Cloves and Mace, of each as much as will lie upon a three pence;
#Text= cut all these as small as possible you can.
#Text=Then take a pound of Sugar, and
#Text= half a pint of water, boil it to a candy-height, then put in the
#Text=Ambergreece and Musk, with three or four spoonfulls of Orange flower water.
#Text=Then put in all the other things and stir them well together, and cast them
#Text= upon plates, and set them to dry: when both sides are dry, take
#Text= Orange-flower-water and Sugar, and Ice them.
#Text=TO MAKE HARTS-HORN GELLY
#Text=
#Text= Take four Ounces of Harts-horn rasped, boil it in four pound of water, till
#Text= it will be a gelly, which you may try upon a plate (it will be so, in four
#Text= or five or six hours gentle boiling) and then pass the clear liquor from
#Text= the horn (which will be a good quart) then set it on the fire again with
#Text= fine Sugar in it to your taste; when that is dissolved (or at the same time
#Text= you put that in) put half a pound of white-wine or Sack into it, and a bag
#Text= of Spice, containing a little Ginger, a stick of Cinnamon bruised, a Nutmeg
#Text= quartered, two or three Cloves, and what other Spice you like, but Pepper.
#Text=As soon as it beginneth to boil, put into it the whites of three or four
#Text= Eggs beaten, and let it boil up gently, till the Eggs harden into a curd.
#Text=Then open it with a spoon, and pour into it the juyce of three or four
#Text= good Limons; then take it presently off the fire, letting it not boil more
